title: McDonald's, Starbucks to Close Russian Locations
summary: McDonald's has about 850 locations in Russia; Burger King, KFC-owner Yum Brands continue to operate through franchises. McDonald's Corp. and Starbucks Corp. said Tuesday they are suspending operations at Russia locations, as U.S. restaurant companies face calls from investors and consumers to reassess ties with the country.

title: What Companies Have Pulled Back From Russia?
summary: Western businesses such as Apple, Boeing and Volkswagen are re-evaluating operations in Russia after its invasion of Ukraine. Russia's invasion of Ukraine has prompted many Western companies across industries to re-evaluate their businesses in Russia. Some have decided to suspend operations in the country, while others have decided to pull out entirely.

title: Biden Rallies Executives Behind Bill Countering China Tech Threat
summary: House, Senate have competing versions of measure that would put $52 billion toward boosting U.S. chip production. WASHINGTON-President Biden is enlisting top executives and governors of two auto-industry states to push Congress to resolve differences and pass legislation aimed at boosting U.S. competitiveness with China.

title: Coca-Cola, PepsiCo Pull Back From Russia as Ukraine Crisis Deepens
summary: McDonald's also said it was temporarily closing its roughly 850 restaurants in the region. Some of America's best-known brands took steps to pull back from Russia on Tuesday, when Coca-Cola Co. said it would suspend operations in the country and McDonald's Corp. said it was temporarily closing its restaurants.

title: Stocks Finish Lower as Oil Rises on Russian Oil Ban
summary: Bond yields and gold prices climbed as investors sought havens. U.S. stocks fell on Tuesday in an erratic session, bouncing between losses and gains as investors tried to keep up with a barrage of headlines. Bond yields, oil and gold prices all rose.

title: Chinese Nickel Giant Tsingshan Faces $8 Billion Trading Loss as Ukraine War Upends Market
summary: Nickel prices soared, prompting the London Metal Exchange to suspend trading in the metal. HONG KONG-Chinese nickel titan Tsingshan Holding Group faces billions of dollars in trading losses, people familiar with the company said, after Russia's war in Ukraine set off an unprecedented rise in the price of a key metal used in stainless steel and electric-vehicle batteries.

title: Apple Plays to Its Two Extremes
summary: Updates to cheapest iPhone and most expensive Mac show how Apple has to appeal to a wide audience. Never known for cheap products, even Apple has to segment its customer base.

title: Shareholder Sues Rivian, Alleging Startup Misled Investors on Vehicle Pricing
summary: Suit alleges Rivian failed to disclose it had underpriced its vehicles and would need to raise prices after its market debut. A shareholder is suing Rivian Automotive Inc., alleging the electric-vehicle startup misled investors by failing to disclose it had underpriced its vehicles and would need to raise prices after its market debut.

title: Better.com to Lay Off More Employees-This Time Not on Zoom
summary: Online mortgage lender's decision comes after CEO was criticized for firing 900 employees over a video call last year. Online mortgage lender Better.com said Tuesday it is laying off more of its workforce, months after the company's chief executive drew criticism for firing 900 employees over a Zoom call.

title: Why Is Gas So Expensive? Ukraine-Russia War Sparks Price Increases Across U.S.
summary: Invasion accelerated rise in already-climbing prices; national average tops $4 a gallon. U.S. gasoline prices have reached records above $4 a gallon, a climb that threatens to hamper economic growth, lift already high inflation and cut down on summer road trips.

title: Elizabeth Holmes: What Happens Next to Theranos Founder Found Guilty of Fraud
summary: Holmes was convicted on four of 11 counts; sentencing is set for September. Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of Theranos Inc., was found guilty Jan. 3 on four counts of criminal fraud against investors. She was acquitted on four counts tied to patients. The jury was unable to reach a unanimous verdict on the remaining three counts tied to investors.

title: Russian Oil Embargo Pushes OPEC to Take Sides
summary: Oil cartel producers can open their taps to help balance the market, but it would mean choosing the West over Moscow. A Russian oil embargo ramps up pressure on the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase production or side with Russia. As the war in Ukraine becomes a proxy conflict in a new Cold War, the cartel can't hope to maintain its current studied neutrality.

title: Russia Set to Ban Commodity Exports Following Western Sanctions
summary: President Putin's decree didn't specify which commodities and countries would be subjected to the export ban. Russian President Vladimir Putin is banning exports of certain commodities and raw materials, according to a decree issued Tuesday evening in Moscow.

title: How Much Oil Does the U.S. Import From Russia and Why Is Biden Banning It?
summary: Despite being the top global producer, the U.S. has turned to Russian crude to service more-isolated coastal markets and keep refineries running at optimal levels. The fracking boom made America the world's biggest oil producer a few years ago, but the U.S. until recently was still importing millions of barrels each day from other parts of the world, including Russia.

title: Office Technology in the Pre-Screen Era: How Much Do You Know?
summary: Yes, the BlackBerry was once cutting edge. Then again, so was the pencil. It's time to test your knowledge in this quiz.. As with so many other things in modern life, we interact with office technology nowadays largely through a screen. But it wasn't always this way. Once upon a time, offices maintained lush supplies of letterhead, envelopes, file folders and all the other delectable paraphernalia of administration, every pad and Post-it Note filled with the promise of the blank slate.

title: Alphabet's Google to Buy Mandiant in $5.4 Billion Deal
summary: Cybersecurity investments have been hot among tech companies, as they beef up those services for customers amid a surge in cyberattacks. Google said it reached a deal to buy cybersecurity company Mandiant Inc. for nearly $5.4 billion, aiming to bolster its cloud unit with more cybersecurity offerings at a time when businesses have seen a wave of attacks on their systems.

title: Google to Test Deal Waters With Mandiant
summary: Picking up relatively small cybersecurity provider for Google Cloud might not trigger extra scrutiny. In going after Mandiant , Google parent Alphabet is essentially betting on its ability to look small.

title: The Technology That Every Hybrid Employee Needs to Make Work Smoother-and More Productive
summary: Workers need a setup to address the particular challenges of dividing their workweek. As workplaces reopen, more of us are splitting our time between home and office-with some third places, like the local coffee shop or co-working space, thrown into the mix. Even if you were one of the lucky people who got equipment and support from your employer's IT team when you set up your home office, it's now time to rethink that setup to address the particular challenges of dividing your workweek (or workday) between different locations.

title: GM and PG&E to Test Program for Electric Vehicles to Boost Power Grid
summary: The companies plan pilot to examine potential of using GM electric vehicles as backup power sources during outages. General Motors Co. and PG&E Corp. plan to test the use of electric vehicles to power homes during outages as the California utility works to reduce the impact of wildfires on its customers.

title: Listen to Oil Prices and You Can Hear Echoes of the 1970s
summary: The Arab oil embargo and the Iranian Revolution offer different templates for what could happen next. When oil prices double or more in a year, bad things often happen. Sometimes that is a recession, as in 1974, 1980 or 2001. Other times, a recession has just started, as in 1990 or 2008. On Monday, the global crude oil benchmark briefly spiked to $139 a barrel, doubling from a year ago, as an embargo on Russian oil exports was discussed. Are these gloomy historical parallels justified, or could this be more like 2017, when oil doubled and everything was hunky-dory?

title: Shell, BP to Withdraw From Russian Oil, Gas
summary: Moves come ahead of what people familiar with the matter say is a plan by the Biden administration to ban Russian oil imports into the U.S.. European oil giants Shell PLC and BP PLC said they were stepping back further from doing business with Russia, with Shell saying it will immediately halt all spot purchase of crude from the country and will phase out its other trading and business dealings.

title: Biggest Gains in Social Responsibility in the Management Top 250
summary: Micron Technology, Whirlpool and T-Mobile are the top three. Micron Technology Inc. posted a bigger gain in its score for social responsibility than any other company in the latest Management Top 250, followed by Whirlpool Corp. and T-Mobile US Inc .

title: The Surge in Gasoline Prices Isn't Slowing Down
summary: Traders and shippers are shunning Russian oil, pulling millions of barrels from global supplies and powering new increases at the pump. Prices at the gas pump are soaring to near record levels across the U.S., threatening to further pressure consumers and an economy already struggling with sky-high inflation.

title: 'As We Work'
summary: The pandemic has upended our work lives. Our new podcast explores the changing workplace-and what you need to know to navigate it.. New episodes of "As We Work" will publish on Tuesdays at 9 a.m. ET. Listen and follow on Spotify, Apple Podcasts or your favorite podcast player.

title: Cryptocurrency Tax Guide 2021-2022, Filing Your Bitcoin and NFT Taxes
summary: The IRS is cracking down on cryptocurrency tax cheating. Cryptocurrency owners, beware: The IRS is trying to strip away excuses for millions of people who aren't complying with the tax rules on them, either inadvertently or on purpose.

title: 2021-2022 Federal Income Tax Brackets and Rates
summary: Proposals in Congress to raise top income-tax rates have failed to gain traction. The tax code currently has seven income-tax brackets for individuals that range from 10% to 37%. The 10% rate takes effect at the first dollar of taxable income, after benefits such as the standard deduction are applied. Each tax rate applies to income in that bracket. So a taxpayer whose last dollars are taxed at 24% will likely have portions of income taxed at 0, 10%, 12% and 22%.

title: Russia's Boardrooms Face Exodus of Western Directors
summary: Western executives and former officials are quitting their posts at Russian companies in the wake of Moscow's invasion of Ukraine, but some are hanging on. A growing number of senior U.S. and European executives and former government officials are quitting their roles on the boards of some of Russia's largest companies, severing another link with the global economy after an exodus of Western businesses.

title: Tom Cotton Compares Reagan and Trump in Speech on GOP's Future
summary: Arkansas senator and possible 2024 presidential candidate is the latest in a series of Reagan Library speakers. Sen. Tom Cotton of Arkansas argued in a high-profile speech Monday evening that presidents Ronald Reagan and Donald Trump share roots in the Republican Party and that those who suggest the GOP must pick a path that embraces one or the other are wrong.

title: Companies Try Help-Wanted Ads on TV
summary: In tight labor market, Domino's, FedEx look for hires through national TV spots; Dunkin' recruits using social-media influencers. Domino's Pizza Inc. began airing a new television commercial several weeks ago, but the ad isn't peddling pizza.

title: Ukraine Conflict Triggers China's Food Insecurities
summary: Food self-sufficiency is a longstanding concern for Chinese policy makers. Recent events are likely to speed efforts to boost crop yields.. Food security and self-sufficiency have long been high on the agenda of Chinese policy makers. Russia's invasion of Ukraine gives Beijing more reasons to focus on the issue. Weaning itself off imported foodstuffs would mean more investment into the biotechnology industry and more widespread use of genetically modified food.

title: Visa, Mastercard Prepare to Raise Credit-Card Fees
summary: The increases, delayed during the pandemic, mean many merchants will pay more when shoppers use credit cards. Visa Inc. and Mastercard Inc. are preparing to increase the fees that many large merchants pay when they accept consumers' credit cards.

title: Expats Quietly Leave Russia Over Financial and Safety Worries
summary: Businesspeople, academics, students take flight amid worry over what comes next in Russia after the country's invasion of Ukraine. It was just an internet rumor: Russia might seize bank accounts of foreigners in the country. But since Russia invaded Ukraine, so many previously unthinkable things had occurred that Jonas Ness, a North Dakota native living outside Moscow, didn't want to chance it.

title: Your Stock Portfolio Needs a Side Hustle
summary: No side hustle? No problem. Play this market trend instead.. The term "side hustle" sounds almost illicit-like Walter White's secret crystal-meth business in "Breaking Bad"-but it is actually both common and respectable. The real high might lie in the stock market.

title: Carbon-Transformation Startup LanzaTech Is Going Public
summary: Company traps waste gas, uses bacteria to turn it into sustainable chemicals and products for customers including Unilever and Coty. LanzaTech NZ Inc. is merging with a special-purpose acquisition company to go public in a deal that values the carbon-capture and transformation company at about $2.2 billion, company officials said.

title: How High Is Inflation? It Depends Which One
summary: Federal Reserve policy makers are closely watching inflation, but probably not the gauge you are using, and theirs isn't quite as high. The inflation numbers that people pay the most attention to and the inflation numbers that the Federal Reserve cares about aren't the same. In the months ahead, those differences could really matter.

title: Russia Can't Fly Without the West-But May Eventually Propel China
summary: Sanctions will devastate Russian aviation by denying it access to Boeing and Airbus parts. They will also give fresh impetus to efforts with China to develop alternatives to Western technology.. Russia's increasing isolation from the West will leave it looking towards China for alternative economic partnerships. Aviation is a prime example: Badly hit by sanctions, the Russian industry has little choice but to double down on collaboration with its big peer to the East.

title: Ukrainians Risk Lives to Keep Russian Gas Flowing
summary: Europe is importing more Russian natural gas than before the invasion. Ukrainian gas pipeline workers put themselves in harm's way to make sure it arrives.. Europe imported more natural gas from Russia in the first 10 days of the war than before the invasion. Keeping it flowing is a crew of intrepid Ukrainians.

title: European Banks Take Brunt of Market Selloff
summary: Ukraine conflict is hitting Europe's banks just as they were shaking off Covid-19 downturn. Most banks in Europe have little direct exposure to Russia. Yet that hasn't stopped investors from fleeing their shares since war broke out in Ukraine.

title: Why Companies Should Let Employees Use Their Personal Smartphones for Work
summary: A study finds that people feel empowered when they can use their personal devices and apps. Many employers still resist the idea of allowing staff to use personal electronic devices at work or install apps of their own choosing on company devices. But a recent study suggests those policies may be misguided.

title: Uber, Lyft and Others Move to Head Off Unions
summary: Ads seek to counter Democratic efforts to reclassify gig workers as employees, which would let many unionize. WASHINGTON- Uber Technologies Inc., Lyft Inc. and other companies that use independent contractors as drivers are launching a campaign to head off Democratic efforts to classify their workers as employees, which would allow them to form unions.

title: Gasoline Price Hits Record High
summary: U.S. drivers are now paying an average $4.173 a gallon at the pump, AAA says. The price for U.S. gasoline hit a record high, tracking a surge in global energy markets and showing how the war in Ukraine is having far-reaching economic consequences.

title: Foreign Companies in China Are Less Optimistic About Investing There
summary: Business-chamber survey finds Covid-19 restrictions, opaque rules and persistent U.S.-China tensions damp sentiment. HONG KONG-Foreign companies in China are feeling less confident about investing in China, citing concerns of slowing economic growth and political tensions with the U.S., an annual survey by an American business group found.
